title: Travels, in various parts of Europe, Asia, and Africa, during a series of thirty years and upwards. By John MacDonald,
author: MacDonald, John
snippet: The Captain of the Dunmore let our Captain know he would send one of his officers on board of us to hear the news, for he had been a great while from England.

title: Bohemian days;
author: Tadlock, Clara Moyse.
snippet: One day we drove ten miles to Dunmore,one of the most interesting places in the vicinity, whosehuge cliffs act as a sea-wall, with here and there shelteredcoves.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: After passing under the groves of Dunmore, and by the Bridge of" See Brown's Picture of Strathearn.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: — Leaving St. FUlan's a lit tie before noon,we crossed the open holm and the hUl which givesname to the vUlage, and passing by the bridge andkirk of Dunduan, entered the beautiful groves,which render the course of the infant Earn so lovely, and admired scenery extremely like that ofthe Trosachs, until the fine plantations and houseof Duneira rose on the left ; a little beyond whichthe pillar erected in 1812, upon Dunmore, to thelate Lord MelvUle, appeared in view ; while, on theright, the white walls of AberuchUl Castle contrasted finely with its contiguous prolixity of shade,and finely undulating lawns.

title: Journal of a tour through the Highlands of Scotland during the summer of MDCCCXXIX.
author: Botfield, Beriah
snippet: This vaUey burst gloriously on our view ;Lord MelvUle's granite pillar, on Dunmore, forming the centre of a lovely picture of the rugged andcloud-capt Grampian mountains, at the foot ofwhich crouched the groves and lawns of Lawers,Duneira, &c. ; and stiU lower the town of Comrie,which, after our descent from the hiUs, we approached by the plain of Dalginross.

title: 'Broken stowage',
author: Bone, David W.
snippet: Ye'll have to carry me on, Captain on to Dunmore or Milford!" The Captain, ill-pleased at the prospect of a halt, however short, in his voyage, hopes that there may be a shift of wind before Holyhead is reached, but the Pilot, glancing to the Formby shore, where everything stands out distinct in the clear north wind, shakes his head weatherwise.

title: 'Broken stowage',
author: Bone, David W.
snippet: When the wind comes strong over Killea on the Hill, the sea folk of Dunmore are early astir, counting the tides and watching for the distant smoke, south away, that tells of a steamer rounding the Coning- beg lightship.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Dundee, with the LordsLinlithgow and Dunmore, shed tears of grief andmortification.
